channel.title: Beggining to learn
channel.description:
Well guys I've decided to start learning some languages. I want to start off with C# because I've heard it's one of the easier ones, and then eventually move my way up to C++
Well, basically what I wanted to know is what the proper tools are. I've got notepad++ and my computer already has the .net frame so how would I save the files and run them? I know I sound like an idiot but don't judge me, I'm just a beginner :o. I've already got my HelloWorld [I've been studying the meanings of the variables, etc] in notepad++ so what should I do now? I've been googling for a while and no help :/
And if any of you have some tips or tutorials or if you recommend me learning something else first or what I should learn next, or what program I should use. Please post. Thanks.

item.title: Beggining to learn
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“inertia, post:17, topic:305112”][quote author=ZeroFreeze link=topic=401372.msg2976250#msg2976250 date=1254300835]
you could start by buying a book for absolute C# (or whatever) beginners that addresses the concept of programming and programs too.
[/quote]C++ for dummies was okay too[/quote]
Are you a troll or just severely stupid?

Read full topic

op is a moron

item.title: Beggining to learn
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Dev-C++ is kinda for C++ and not for C#

An alternative to VC# could be MonoDevelop, but I wouldn’t recommed it, as it’s sigifnicantly worse than VC# and doesn’t really support proper RAD.

Read full topic

item.title: Beggining to learn
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

You could try Dev-C++. I don’t know what it’s like compared to the other compilers/ide’s out there though, it was just the primary compiler used in a c++ guide I had years ago. It might be outdated but I find the UI simple and intuitive, and it’s easy to mod the compiler too.

Read full topic

item.title: Beggining to learn
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Visual Studio

Visual Studio Express | Now Visual Studio Community

Try out Visual Studio Community for a fully-featured IDE; An updated alternative to Visual Studio Express. Download Visual Studio Community for free today.

Read full topic

item.title: Beggining to learn
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

First create a C# project (Possibly a console one), then Build Solution. I think there are detailed tutorials available on the topic at the Microsoft website.

Read full topic

if i feel the need to code in c#, i append .net sdk path to %path%, then just execute csc.
